description: Core syntax and grammar: clause structure, complementation, subordination, coordination, information structure.

topics.name: Constituency and Functions
coreClaims: Constituents form hierarchical structures (phrases inside clauses).
Grammatical functions (subject/object/complement/adjunct) differ from word class labels.
practice: Bracket a sentence into NP/VP/PP units.
Explain function-role: 'NP' can be subject or object depending on position/structure.

topics.name: Clause Types and Subordination
coreClaims: Independent vs dependent clauses behave differently with respect to tense, embedding, and linkage.
Subordinate clauses can act as complements or adjuncts.
practice: Classify subordinate clause role (complement vs adjunct).
Diagnose common learner errors: fragment vs stylistic non-finite clause.

topics.name: Coordination and Parallelism
coreClaims: Coordination joins comparable structures; mismatched coordination often creates processing difficulty.
Parallelism is both a grammatical and rhetorical constraint.
practice: Repair parallelism errors without changing meaning.
Explain why a coordination is unbalanced (category/function mismatch).

topics.name: Complementation
coreClaims: Verbs and adjectives license specific complement patterns (that-clauses, infinitives, -ing clauses).
Choice of complement often shifts meaning (promise vs persuade patterns).
practice: Write a brief usage note: what patterns are acceptable in academic register.
